repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Several warnings were fixed, C expressions were improved. There are still some warnings pending:

```
WARNING: unknown config value 'latex_paper_size' in override, ignoring
loading intersphinx inventory from https://docs.python.org/3/objects.inv...
building [mo]: targets for 0 po files that are out of date
building [html]: targets for 57 source files that are out of date
updating environment: [new config] 57 added, 0 changed, 0 removed
reading sources... [100%] src/userguide/wrapping_CPlusPlus
looking for now-outdated files... none found
pickling environment... done
checking consistency... /Users/matus/dev/cython/docs/src/reference/interfacing_with_other_code.rst: WARNING: document isn't included in any toctree
/Users/matus/dev/cython/docs/src/reference/limitations.rst: WARNING: document isn't included in any toctree
/Users/matus/dev/cython/docs/src/reference/special_mention.rst: WARNING: document isn't included in any toctree
done
preparing documents... done
writing output... [100%] src/userguide/wrapping_CPlusPlus
WARNING: LaTeX command 'latex' cannot be run (needed for math display), check the imgmath_latex setting
```

I  was not sure if .rst files not included in toctree can be removed or not (they are basically empty).

The rationale for migration `:c:type:` to `:c:expr:` is following link:

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63080103/how-to-reference-built-in-c-types-with-rst

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
Python object return type, like Python functions, will return a ``None``
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -457,10 +457,10 @@ C functions, on the other hand, can have parameters of any type, since they're
 passed in directly using a normal C function call.
 
 C Functions declared using :keyword:`cdef` or the ``@cfunc`` decorator with a
-Python object return type, like Python functions, will return a :keyword:`None`
+Python object return type, like Python functions, will return a ``None`

@@ -97,8 +97,8 @@ match the C ones, and in some cases they shouldn't or can't. In particular:
 
 #. If the header file uses macros to define constants, translate them into a
    normal external variable declaration.  You can also declare them as an
-   :keyword:`enum` if they contain normal :c:type:`int` values.  Note that
-   Cython considers :keyword:`enum` to be equivalent to :c:type:`int`, so do
+   :keyword:`enum` if they contain normal :c:expr:`int` values.  Note that
+   Cython considers :keyword:`enum` to be equivalent to :c:expr:`int`, so do

@@ -651,25 +651,25 @@ Windows and wide character APIs
 -------------------------------
 
 Windows system APIs natively support Unicode in the form of
-zero-terminated UTF-16 encoded :c:type:`wchar_t*` strings, so called
+zero-terminated UTF-16 encoded :c:expr:`wchar_t*` strings, so called
 "wide strings".
 
 By default, Windows builds of CPython define :c:type:`Py_UNICODE` as
-a synonym for :c:type:`wchar_t`. This makes internal :obj:`unicode`
+a synonym for :c:expr:`wchar_t`. This makes internal :obj:`unicode`

comment_data.body:
When we use `:c:type:` sphinx is trying to find definition of `int` type which does not exist. This yields warnings during generating of documentation:
```
/Users/matus/dev/cython/docs/src/userguide/external_C_code.rst:98: WARNING: Unparseable C cross-reference: 'int'
Invalid C declaration: Expected identifier in nested name, got keyword: int [error at 3]
  int
  ---^
``` 
The fix is to use `c:expr:` instead - see https://stackoverflow.com/questions/63080103/how-to-reference-built-in-c-types-with-rst for details.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -97,8 +97,8 @@ match the C ones, and in some cases they shouldn't or can't. In particular:
 
 #. If the header file uses macros to define constants, translate them into a
    normal external variable declaration.  You can also declare them as an
-   :keyword:`enum` if they contain normal :c:type:`int` values.  Note that
-   Cython considers :keyword:`enum` to be equivalent to :c:type:`int`, so do
+   :keyword:`enum` if they contain normal :c:expr:`int` values.  Note that
+   Cython considers :keyword:`enum` to be equivalent to :c:expr:`int`, so do

comment_data.body:
There is no definition of `wchar_t` type. Using `:c:type:` is yielding errors during generating of documentation:
```
/Users/matus/dev/cython/docs/src/tutorial/strings.rst:653: WARNING: Unparseable C cross-reference: 'wchar_t*'
Invalid C declaration: Expected end of definition. [error at 7]
  wchar_t*
  -------^
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -651,25 +651,25 @@ Windows and wide character APIs
 -------------------------------
 
 Windows system APIs natively support Unicode in the form of
-zero-terminated UTF-16 encoded :c:type:`wchar_t*` strings, so called
+zero-terminated UTF-16 encoded :c:expr:`wchar_t*` strings, so called
 "wide strings".
 
 By default, Windows builds of CPython define :c:type:`Py_UNICODE` as
-a synonym for :c:type:`wchar_t`. This makes internal :obj:`unicode`
+a synonym for :c:expr:`wchar_t`. This makes internal :obj:`unicode`

commit.message: Fix sphinx build warnings, improve C expressions
